importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the US military attack on a Venezuelan vessel, which led to the capture of two survivors and heightened regional tensions.
The date of the previous US strike mentioned in context, indicating a pattern of escalating military actions over recent weeks.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: A period of intensified US military operations against Venezuelan vessels, marking a significant escalation in US-Venezuela tensions.

keyTakeAways: The US conducted a military strike on a vessel allegedly carrying drugs from Venezuela, marking at least the sixth such attack in recent weeks.
The attack resulted in the capture of two survivors, making it the first reported incident where survivors were recovered from a US strike.
President Donald Trump confirmed the attack, describing the vessel as a 'drug-carrying submarine' and justifying it as targeting a major drug trafficking operation.
US officials, including Secretary of State Marco Rubio, labeled the attacks as targeting 'narco-terrorists', though they declined to confirm survivor details.
The incident has drawn international criticism, with UN human rights experts calling the strikes 'extrajudicial executions'.
Venezuela President Nicolás Maduro accused the US of attempting to make Venezuela an 'American colony' and called for international intervention.
Trinidad and Tobago launched an investigation into the deaths of two of its citizens, allegedly victims of a prior US strike.
The US has significantly increased its military presence in the Caribbean, with around 10,000 troops and B-52 bombers conducting surveillance operations.
There are reports that Trump authorized CIA covert operations in Venezuela and considered launching attacks on Venezuelan soil.
Narco-subs—homemade, fibreglass and plywood submarines—are increasingly used to transport large quantities of cocaine, often undetected and then sunk after delivery.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The United States conducted a military strike on a vessel allegedly carrying drugs from Venezuela, resulting in the capture of two survivors—a first in a series of at least six such attacks in recent weeks. President Donald Trump confirmed and justified the attack, calling the vessel a 'drug-carrying submarine' and claiming it targeted a major drug trafficking operation. The US government, including Secretary of State Marco Rubio, labeled the actions as targeting 'narco-terrorists', though they declined to confirm survivor details. Venezuela’s President Nicolás Maduro accused the US of attempting to make Venezuela an 'American colony', while Venezuela’s UN Ambassador Samuel Moncada condemned the attacks and called for UN intervention. Trinidad and Tobago is investigating the deaths of two of its citizens in a prior attack, raising concerns about civilian casualties. The increased US military presence in the Caribbean—such as 10,000 troops and B-52 bomber flights—has heightened regional fears. International human rights experts have condemned the strikes as 'extrajudicial executions', adding moral and legal scrutiny to the operation.
title: US captures two survivors after attack on Venezuela 'drug sub'
